abstract.text: The details of your app-specific content that someone might search
for on their devices.

legalNotices.copyright: Copyright © 2025 Apple Inc. All rights reserved.

inlineContent.text: A
uniquely identifies a part of your app’s
content, and provides the metadata that Spotlight indexes and uses
to find that content later. As part of indexing your app’s content,
you create searchable items and fill them with details about your
app’s content and where to find it. After indexing the content, you
can then execute queries using the Core Spotlight APIs to find the
items you indexed. People can also use the system’s Spotlight search
interface to find your app’s content.
When you create or update content in your app, create a
for that content if you want it to be searchable. A searchable item
contains identification strings you use to locate that item in your
content and a
object with details about
the item. For the metadata, you typically want to provide values for
the
and
attributes at a minimum.
If you’re indexing a file on disk, provide a value for the
attribute. Fill in as many other attributes as makes sense for the content
you’re indexing.
After creating a searchable item, index it using a
object. As you update your app’s content, update your
objects for that content and index them right away. If you delete content,
similarly delete the searchable items from the index. Keeping your app’s
indexes current ensures that searches return valid information. For more
information on indexing your content, see

abstract.text: Add search capabilities to your app, and index your content so
people can find it from Spotlight and Safari.
A key associated with a custom attribute for a searchable item.
An object that displays localized text in search results related to your app.
An object that represents a person in the context of search results.
Indicates that the activity type to continue is a search or query.
Provides the key for the current query in the info dictionary of the user activity object.
An on-device index for your app’s searchable content.
The details of your app-specific content that someone might search
for on their devices.
The set of options that contain metadata-associated summarization and
prioritization of a searchable item.
Associates an app entity with this searchable item.
The set of attributes that contain metadata associated with the item in a
object.
Compares two items by rank and returns the result.
An optional identifier that represents the domain or owner of the item.
The date after which the searchable item should no longer exist.
Intializes a new searchable item with the relevant fields populated from the provided app entity.
Intializes a new searchable item with the relevant fields populated from the provided app entity.
Returns a searchable item associated with the specified identifier, domain identifier, and attribute set.
A Boolean value that indicates whether to treat the item as an
update instead of a new item.
The value that uniquely identifies the searchable item within your app.
Indicates that the activity type to continue is related to a searchable item.
The key you use to access a searchable item in a user activity object.
The detailed metadata for a searchable item.
The uniform type identifier (UTI) of the item.
The file URL of the content to index.
A localized string that contains the name of the item, suitable to display in the user interface.
The title of the item.
Create a description for your app’s content and add it to a Spotlight
index to make it searchable.

doc://com.apple.corespotlight/documentat.title: Adding your app’s content to Spotlight indexes

abstract.text: Enable Apple Intelligence to summarize and prioritize app
content using Spotlight extensions.

doc://com.apple.corespotlight/documentat.title: Enabling Apple Intelligence summarization and prioritization

abstract.text: Search for app-specific content and refine search results using
predicates and filters.

doc://com.apple.corespotlight/documentat.title: Searching for information in your app

abstract.text: The root class of most Objective-C class hierarchies, from which subclasses inherit a basic interface to the runtime system and the ability to behave as Objective-C objects.
A protocol that enables an object to be encoded and decoded for archiving and distribution.
A protocol that objects adopt to provide functional copies of themselves.
The group of methods that are fundamental to all Objective-C objects.
A protocol that enables encoding and decoding in a manner that is robust against object substitution attacks.
A type that can be hashed into a `Hasher` to produce an integer hash value.
A type that can be compared for value equality.
A type with a customized textual representation.
A type with a customized textual representation suitable for debugging purposes.
A type whose instances can be encoded, and appropriately passed, as elements of a C `va_list`.
